author.name: Andy Matuschak
author.description: More wonder, more insight, more capacity, more joy!\n\nCurrently exploring tools that augment human memory and attention.

author.name: Ness Labs
author.description: The learning community for ambitious knowledge workers. Join us to think better, learn faster, and work happier: https://t.co/aw5gE8xtMw 🧠✨

html:
Some days, I wake up feeling trapped in a prison of procrastination. It feels almost impossible to get anything done. How do you get back on track when it seems like your motivation is gone?

Learn more 👇

https://t.co/9seXaDpbPK

author.name: Nick Milo 🗺
author.description: You deserve a guilt-free place to think and generate insights\nMastodon: @nickmilo@pkm.social

html: When you do less highlights something miraculous happens: you have more time for insights.\n\nThis is what happens when you shift from passive thinking to active, engaged thinking: you go from note-taker to note-maker.

author.name: George Silverman | The MindSkills Guy
author.description: Learn (And Teach!) the Essential Skills to Win at Everything, From Critical Thinking to High-Stakes Problem-Solving to Heat-of-the-Moment Emotional Control

html: Using a TfT (Tool for Thought) like Obsidian @obsdmd and Napkin @napkin_ideas will increase your functional IQ by >20 points, help you drink from the firehose, and make your life calmer. \n\nUsing them feels like ethical cheating.

author.description: We build your space to think. ❤️🧠🚀

author.name: Ness Labs
author.description: The learning community for ambitious knowledge workers. Join us to think better, learn faster, and work happier: https://t.co/aw5gE8xtMw 🧠✨

html:
So many things to do, so little time. When you juggle work, personal projects, and are hoping to have any sort of social life, managing your time can feel like an impossible endeavour.

Learn more 👇

https://t.co/bSRCiERCs7

author.name: George Pór #StandWithUkraine
author.description: Researcher of enhancing CI & collective wisdom @ all scales up to #PlanetarySapience w/ knowledge ecology, #symmathesy, lore, inner/outer technologies. @RnDAO__

html: @lovevolv @peterkaminski @hrheingold @tomatlee @NoraBateson @WardCunningham @TrailMarks @hollygrimm @KERNEL0x @cryptowanderer @0xMeem @daonia_ @CSenseMakers @braddegraf @juneholley @gardenfelder @ma_parent I’m pondering what could be a more useful contribution of the participants in future convos to the planetary wisdom commons, keeping our focus on wisdom gardening itself or bringing our shared attention to a specific use case, e.g. cultivating wisdom in our group or in Kernel.

author.name: Experimental Learning
author.description: In pursuit of a rational approach to human learning. | spaced repetition guy | working @rem_note | https://t.co/L9DNzUYWlq…

html: they don't use any meaningful goal (or a "meta-goal" like interest/novelty) to decide what is worth learning and end up memorizing everything. forgetting could be as important as learning to ensure garbage is pruned out and high quality generalizations/knowledge remain https://t.co/JoL3cPD9w6

author.name: TfT Hacker - Exploring Tools for Thought and PKM
author.description: Exploring Tools for Thought space and PKM, with focus on tools like Obsidian, Tana, Craft, LogSeq, RemNote, AthensResearch, OneNote, etc https://t.co/GyMiAikIl1

html:
So, the lesson is, PDSA is a useful tool for getting your TfT system optimized, but its a serious investment. My advice:

1) Determine the big problems you need to solve
2) Try PDSA loops on the problem
3) Stick with it until you have resolved the problem.

author.name: TfT Hacker - Exploring Tools for Thought and PKM
author.description: Exploring Tools for Thought space and PKM, with focus on tools like Obsidian, Tana, Craft, LogSeq, RemNote, AthensResearch, OneNote, etc https://t.co/GyMiAikIl1

html:
I did these loops over multiple months, increasing and decreasing time, the number of things to read, and so on.

Each loop was a week so that I could iterate the process fast.

As I went through each loop, I documented the plan and, during the study phase, "the results".

author.name: TfT Hacker - Exploring Tools for Thought and PKM
author.description: Exploring Tools for Thought space and PKM, with focus on tools like Obsidian, Tana, Craft, LogSeq, RemNote, AthensResearch, OneNote, etc https://t.co/GyMiAikIl1

html:
Why is this relevant for TfT? We rarely find the perfect worklfow or approach to some problem we want to solve on our first attempt.

Rather we need to define the goal and then start multiple loops of testing our theories until it finally succeeds.

Let me give you an example.

author.name: TfT Hacker - Exploring Tools for Thought and PKM
author.description: Exploring Tools for Thought space and PKM, with focus on tools like Obsidian, Tana, Craft, LogSeq, RemNote, AthensResearch, OneNote, etc https://t.co/GyMiAikIl1

html: In this article, Cedric calls our attention to one sad reality. While it is easy to plan and get started (Plan, Do), we often fail to do the Study (analyze their results) and Act (adjust our approach).\n\nHe encourages us to "finish the loop" even if it seems like it won't succeed.

author.name: TfT Hacker - Exploring Tools for Thought and PKM
author.description: Exploring Tools for Thought space and PKM, with focus on tools like Obsidian, Tana, Craft, LogSeq, RemNote, AthensResearch, OneNote, etc https://t.co/GyMiAikIl1

html: The idea of PDSA is that it involves multiple loops of PDSA.\n\nRarely in life do we reach our intended goals with just one attempt, rather we succeed over multiple iterations, with each iteration getting closer to the desired result. https://t.co/589nfvLYZy

author.name: phil jones (he/him - ele) @interstar@artoot.xyz
author.description:
anarchy, abstraction ... systems, patterns, form.

https://t.co/W6dDzEEQP0

Also at https://t.co/Enwg7ZuD9c

html:
The point of a PKM / personal bicycle for the mind is surely to augment my own individuality and idiosyncrasies. 

If, instead, it gives me some crunch of everyone else's individuality, what am I getting?

\5
